author: Daniel Clark
title: Protests as council rules that Fracking and Brexit are 'not appropriate for debate' - Devon Live
text:
Protests as council rules that Fracking and Brexit are 'not appropriate for debate' South Hams District Council did not debate the two motions at their meeting last week Share Daniel Clark Local Democracy Reporter 17:39, 5 OCT 2018 Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get Daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Fracking and Brexit were ruled ‘out of scope’ and not eligible for debate at last week’s South Hams District Council meeting.
Green Party councillor Jacqi Hodgson had put forward two notice of motions – one to object to fracking and support a national ban on it, and the second to call for a People’s Vote on Brexit.
But Cllr Tom Holway, chairman of the council, following consultation with the council’s monitoring officer, ruled that neither topic were considered appropriate to be debated by the Council. Read More Flying Scotsman in Devon: Here's everything you need to know
Explaining the decision, a council spokesman said: “A motion regarding the People’s Vote was submitted to full Council by Cllr Jacqi Hodgson. It was not debated by the council after our Monitoring Officer, in consultation with the Chairman of the Council, ruled it to be out of scope.
“This means that because the motion was not considered to relate to services that the council provided, commissioned or formally contributed to, then it was not appropriate for it to be debated by the Council.”
Devon for Europe campaigners had protested outside Follaton House, South Hams Council’s HQ, ahead of the meeting, as 52.9 per cent of South Hams residents in 2016 who voted in the referendum voted to remain in the EU. South Hams protesters
Peter Sturdgess, Secretary of Devon For Europe, said: “I am hugely disappointed that my council has chosen to reject this opportunity to discuss the effects of Brexit on our local communities.” Read More
